R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes/ketones (UAL) to unsaturated alcohols (UOL) is a crucial reaction process in the fine chemical industry. Numerous efforts have been made to hydrogenate the target CO group to UOL due to the CC bond being more sensitive to reduction from both kinetics and thermodynamics. The key issue to designing catalysts with high performance is investigating and determining the structure-performance relationship in the selective hydrogenation of UAL. In this Review, the adsorption and activation mechanism of the reactants, and the influences of catalysts structures (electronic effects, synergistic effects, interfacial effects, and geometric effects) are comprehensively discussed. Additionally, the single-atom site catalysts and related catalysts including single-atom-site catalysts, dual-atom-site catalysts, nano-single-atom-site catalysts, and single-atom alloys, that applicated in UAL selective hydrogenation are systematically reviewed with a focus on the selective-enhancing mechanism. Finally, a brief perspective is provided to demonstrate the challenges as well as opportunities for rational designing advanced catalysts toward selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Aldehydes/ketones Selective hydrogenation Catalyst designation Nanocatalysts Single-atom site catalysts Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes/ketones (UAL) to the corresponding unsaturated alcohols (UOL) is an important process in fine chemical engineering, with wide-ranging applications of the product in pharmaceutical synthesis, agrochemicals synthesis, petrochemicals, fragrances production, and many other fields [1–5]. Nevertheless, the side reaction pathways produce saturated aldehydes (SAL) or saturated alcohols (SOL) by the hydrogenation of the CC bond. The conventional stoichiometric reaction process using NaBH4, LiAlH4, and other reducing agents performs high selectivity of UOL but generates a large amount of inorganic waste [6–9]. Afterward, an ecologically friendly and easily separable heterogeneous hydrogenation process was developed to replace the conventional stoichiometric method. While a serious challenge in the heterogeneous system needed to be overcome is the low selectivity due to the CC bond being more thermodynamically favorable with the bond energy of 615 kJ/mol compared to 715 kJ/mol of the target CO bond [10,11]. Thus, investigating the relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic performance is an effective way to rationally design catalysts toward high UOL selectivity. Over the past years, many notable efforts have been made for designing high-performance catalysts in selective hydrogenation UAL to UOL [12–16]. Group VIII metals, such as Ni, Pt, Pd et al., are popular active components due to their unfilled d-band [17,18]. Nonetheless, the group VIII monometallic catalysts have certain limitations because of their intrinsic electronic properties. As a result, bimetallic catalysts or monometallic catalysts with strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) were developed to alter the electronic state of the primary active metal species [19–21]. Besides, electrophilic sites, such as acid sites, oxygen vacancies (Ov), and metal modes of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have been utilized to enhance the catalytic performance by prioritizing adsorbing the polar CO bond through the terminal O atom [22–24]. Moreover, generating new active sites at the metal-support interface has also attracted lots of attention [25,26]. Additionally, catalysts with active metals confining in porous materials (e.g. SiO2, metal oxides, and MOFs) have been synthesized with the aim of reducing the accessibility of CC to the active site and increasing the probability of CO activation [27–29]. Furthermore, single-atom-site catalysts (SASCs) featuring 100% metal atom utilization, uniform single active sites, and low coordination environment of active sites have also generated growing interest from researchers and provided new ideas for the catalyst exploitation in the selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL [30,31]. Previous reviews have extensively discussed the reaction rules of UAL hydrogenation such as catalyst preparation, the fundamental mechanism, kinetics and modeling, substrate structure, and the reactor [32–39]. While, because of the complex and diverse active center of heterogeneous supported catalysts and the impact of supports and the surrounding microenvironments, it is hard to accurately design efficient catalysts and obtained the predicted desired catalytic performance. Therefore, the exclusive and comprehensive investigation regarding the structure-performance relationships of the catalyst is quite essential. Herein, we systematically summarize recent representative progress on the selective hydrogenation of UAL (including UAL molecules which not only contain both CO and CC but also CO and other unsaturated bonds such as -C6H5, -C4H3O, CO et al.) in the heterogeneous system (gas-liquid-solid tri-phase and gas-solid system) over NPs/SASCs, with a focus on in-depth investigating and understanding structure-performance relationship. Firstly, the mechanisms of the adsorption and activation of UAL and H2 are elaborated. Then, the electronic effect, synergistic effect, interfacial effect, and geometric effect of nanocatalysts are discussed based on the typical catalytic regulation theory and method of heterogeneous catalysis. After, recent explorations and findings of SASCs/related catalysts for the hydrogenation of UAL to UOL are summarized, and their unique catalytic mechanisms are revealed through advanced characterization and DFT calculation. Finally, a brief perspective of designing high-performance NPs/SASCs for selective hydrogenations of UAL is pointed out. 2 Theoretical study of selective hydrogenation of UAL 2.1 Adsorption of substrates/UAL Adsorption of substrates is one of the vital steps in heterogeneous catalysis, as it has a great influence on the ensuing reaction pathway [40]. In the process of selective hydrogenation of UAL, the selectivity of the desired product is determined by the adsorption of CC and CO bonds on active sites [41]. According to the research of Sautet et al., there are nine possible adsorption modes of UAL (acrolein, butenal, 3-methyl-2-butenal, cinnamaldehyde) on Pt/Pd surface, as shown in Fig. 1 [42,43]. When the UAL molecule is adsorbed through the CC bond, such as η2 diσcc and η2 πcc mode, the substrates can be regarded as alkenes with a substituent of CHO/CO. Conversely, in the case of only the CO bond is adsorbed, the substrates can be viewed as aldehydes/ketones substituted by the vinyl group, which includes the η1 on-top, η2 diσco, and η2 πco modes. Furthermore, the η3 and η4 mode in a quasiplanar configuration displays the simultaneous adsorption of both CO and CC. The η1 on-top, η2 diσco, and η2 πco modes are conducive to the selective hydrogenation of CO to produce UOL, while the diσcc and πcc adsorption modes tend to activate the CC bond and generate SAL, the last two planar adsorption mode η3 and η4 are more likely to produce SOL since both CO and CC are activated. Particle size and crystal faces of metal components are critical factors that influence the adsorption of UAL [44–46]. Partial hydrogenation reaction of UAL is structure-sensitive. For instance, the activity and selectivity of acrolein hydrogenation over Ag/TiO2 were increased with the enlargement of particle size [47]. On the contrary, the hydrogenation of 2-cyclohexenone is structure-insensitive and the catalytic performance did not change with altering metal particle size [48]. The hydrogenation of citral is deemed as a secondary structure-insensitive reaction as the turnover frequency (TOF) was promoted with the increasing of Pt particle sizes in the range of 1–5 nm, whereas only a tiny alteration was observed with varying Pt particle sizes between 5 and 30 nm [49]. Apart from particle size, crystal faces also influence the adsorption and activation of UAL. Different crystal faces have distinct coordination numbers and atomic arrangements, such as the surface atomic coordination numbers of (111), (100), and (110) crystal faces in the face-centered-cubic (fcc) structure are 9, 8, and 7 respectively, and the surface energy of (111) is higher than (100) [50,51]. The Pt (111) is preferred to adsorb the substrate by di-σ mode, the Pt (100) and Pd (111) tend to adsorb the substrate by planar adsorption mode, and the Pt (110) surface always adopts πcc mode [42,52]. The crystal face determines the adsorption spatial orientation of the substrates, and the same crystal face of different metals also has different adsorption properties. (see Section 3.1). The interaction of the substrate with the active metal can be affected by its electronic properties. The d-band theory considers that the d-band vacancy enables the metal to accept electrons from the substrate and activate them at the same time [53,54]. When the d-band vacancy closely matches the electron transfer number of the reaction, which is 1 in the carbonyl hydrogenation, the catalyst can exhibit better catalytic performance. Hence, metals with filled d-band such as Ag, Au, and Cu are inactive in UAL hydrogenation [49,55]. In addition, metals with wider d-band, like Os and Ir, show stronger repulsive interaction with CC, leading to better selectivity of UOL but poor activity overall. Pd and Pt with the narrower d-band are commonly used active metal components that exhibit low selectivity but high activity. Fortunately, by introducing promoters, such as the second metal, support, and other additions, the intrinsic electronic properties of the metal species can be modified, resulting in an optimal balance of activity and selectivity through electronic and geometric adjustments. Such modification strategies are further discussed in Sections 3.1 and 3.2. Except being adsorbed on active metal sites, the UAL molecule can also be activated on electrophilic sites through the lone electron pair of the O atom of the terminal CO group, and subsequently hydrogenated by H atoms which spilled over the catalyst surface or adsorbed on nearby metal sites [56,57]. Heretofore, the majority of catalysts have been designed based on this mechanism. In bimetallic catalysts, the lower electronegativity second metal donates electrons to the original active metal and itself transformed into a new electrophilic site. The electron-enriched original metal weakens the activation of CC through the repulsive four-electron interaction and is more favorable for the activation of H2. Such synergistic mechanism also exists between active metal and electrophilic sites on the support, such as acid sites, Ov, and the metal nodes of MOFs (see Section 3.2). Furthermore, the catalytic performance of the catalyst can be enhanced by the electron transfer at the metal-support interface actuated by SMSI by generating plenty of active sites that optimize the substrate adsorption (see Section 3.3). In some cases, poor activity may be obtained even though there are plenty of electrophilic sites for UAL activation. This is likely because of the difficulty of H2 dissociation on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the dissociation of H2 should also be considered in addition to the activation of UAL, which is discussed in the following pages [58]. The activation of UAL can be affected by the geometry structure of catalysts through steric effects of supports and crystal surface influence of active metal.[59–61] Porous materials such as SiO2, metal oxides, and MOFs confine metal species to space-isolated pores not only inhibit CC hydrogenation but also promote the stability of metal components. That is controlling the diffusion mode and penetration orientation of substrates via the channel of supports is a valuable approach to reducing the interaction between CC and active site and increasing the CO adsorption probability. (see Section 3.4). Additionally, it should be noted that UAL molecules have a similar hydrogenation mechanism owing to the resembling construction, but the details are different due to varied substituents [62]. Apart from the aromatic ring being less active in hydrogenation reactions and always contributing to high selectivity, the substituents also have a significant impact on the electronic state of the UAL molecule, influencing the oxidation reducibility of CO. The aromatic ring can be serving as the electron-donating group and supply electrons to the CO bond, so that the benzaldehyde molecule is easily reduced [63,64]. Besides, the phenyl group also facilitates the adsorption and hydrogenation of CO on larger metal particles by preventing the molecule from parallel adsorption on the metal surface [65,66]. Moreover, the presence of aliphatic substituents can also induce steric effects that enhance the adsorption of the CO bond [67]. Another factor concerning UAL adsorption is the concentration of UAL, as higher densities of crotonaldehyde can result in decreased selectivity toward the formation of crotyl alcohol due to the CC group approaching the metal surface [68]. 2.2 Dihydrogen/H2 activation and spillover Dihydrogen/H2 activation is another critical step in the selective hydrogenation of UAL. H2 dissociation typically occurs through homolytic or heterolytic pathways depending on the environment of the metal center ( Fig. 2) [69]. Homolytic pathway is commonly happening on uniformly bulk metal surfaces with the metal bonds to any other metal atom in the coordination range on the plane to form a metal-metal pair, where the two hydrogen atoms dissociated and attached to the two metal centers as M-H bonds. The covalent M-H bond sometimes transfers to a hydridic state (M-H δ−) depending on the electronegativity of active metals, like in the case of H2 dissociated on alkali and alkaline earth metals. The brönsted or lewis acid site on the catalyst surface can also capture electrons from H atoms and create protons [66,70]. On the other hand, the heterolytic pathway occurs when the active metal bonds to a lewis base forming a metal-base pair (lewis base = O, S, N, P) [71]. In the heterolysis process, metals with partially unoccupied d-bands can accept σ electrons of H2, then donate d-electrons to the σ * antibonding orbital of H2, and the H-H bond is weakened and broken to form ion pairs (H+/H−). The H+/H− pair can greatly increase the selectivity of UOL compared to the H atoms dissociated by the homolytic pathway because the H+ is a good electrophile to interact with the O end of the CO bond and H− affects the C atom as a nucleophile [72]. However, the activation energy barrier of the heterolytic pathway is much higher than the homolytic pathway, resulting in the activity being restrained though enough adsorption sites of UAL have existed (see Section 4) [73]. The adsorption and activation of H2 are significantly affected by the electronegativity of the active metal [74]. Higher electronegativity results in greater electron density within d-bands, leading to an increase in the homolytic dissociation of dihydrogen/H2 molecules. On the contrary, lower electronegativity promotes the formation of the H+/H− pair. Moreover, the intrinsic electronic state of the active metal can be modulated by the second metal, supports, defective sites, and the surface coordination environment of the catalyst, thereby affecting the adsorption and activation of dihydrogen/H2 [75]. The spillover of H atoms should be taken into consideration when the substrate adsorption sites and the H2 dissociation active centers are separated on the catalyst surface [76,77]. The procedure of hydrogen spillover over nonreducible aluminosilicate is currently unclear, while the mechanism of H species migrating along the reducible metal oxide surface has been shown to involve coherent proton-electron movements [78,79]. The movement of H atoms on nonreducible support, such as Al2O3, is proven orders of magnitude slower and restricted to a much shorter distance compared to that on reducible support [80]. Besides, spillover H atoms can regulate the surface electronic properties of the catalyst, such as reducing metal oxides on the surface and forming Ov on the reducible oxide support [81–83]. In summary, the adsorption and activation of UAL and H2 are two aspects that influence the selectivity of UOL. Within the extensive research on UAL hydrogenation, the regulation of UAL adsorption has gained much attention, while the impact of hydrogen activation is comparatively understudied. Therein, the electronic state of the active metal, electrophilic sites, SMSI, and the physical structure of the catalysts are associated with the adsorption tendency of the UAL molecule. The activation and spillover of dihydrogen/H2 play an important role in determining whether the activated substrate can be further hydrogenated. 3 Regulation of NPs and the function mechanism To enhance the hydrogenation performance of catalysts, various catalyst design strategies have been developed, including controlling the metal electronic state, fabricating alloys, utilizing functional metal oxide supports, confining metal NPs into porous materials, selective poisoning, etc. While a catalyst synthesis strategy often produces multiple effects during the reaction process, and the catalytic performance of the catalyst ultimately results from several factors [84–86]. To investigate the structure-performance relationship of catalysts, these strategies are organized and discussed from the perspective of electronic effect, synergistic effect, interfacial effect, and geometric effect. 3.1 Electronic effects Catalysts reported having electronic effects are summarized in Table 1. As mentioned in Section 2.1, the adsorption tendencies of UAL over monometallic catalysts are influenced by their inherent electronic properties, including particle size, crystal faces, and d-band, et al. The impact of electron properties of metal species and modification methods are discussed in this section. 3.1.1 Particle size and low coordination sites Atoms situated on the edge, kink, terrace, corner, metal-support interfaces, and interior have distinct coordination environments and electronic properties [95]. These diverse catalytic sites lead to different adsorption modes of UAL [96,97]. For instance, the flat Pt (111) surface exhibits a preference for UAL adsorption via the terminal CO bond, while Pt (100) tends to absorb both CC and CO. Low coordination sites of Pt NPs, such as defects, steps, edges, and corners, favor the πcc adsorption mode [98–100]. Satsuma et al. indicated that the selectivity increased as the boosted Pt surface coordination number (steps < (100) < (111)) with the diσco adsorption mode became more tendentious [101]. Furthermore, catalytic sites of different types of metal also exhibit diverse performances. For Pt-based catalysts, low coordination sites show a preference for adsorbing CC through the πcc mode performing low selectivity [102]. In contrast, corner and edge sites of Pd-based catalysts tend to adsorb the UAL molecule with the perpendicular configuration (η1), leading to the high selectivity of UOL [42]. Reducing metal particle size makes for higher electron deficiency and a great number of low-coordinated atoms [103]. For Pd-based catalysts, downsizing the particle size is an efficient approach to enhancing the activity and selectivity in UAL hydrogenation [104–106]. Wells et al. reduced the Pd particle size from 2.5 nm (PdA1) to 1.4 nm (PdB1), resulting in more CO linear adsorbed sites ascribed to the increased corners and edges of the PdB1 NPs [52]. The hydrogenation of furfural on PdB1 demonstrated high selectivity of 67% at 79% conversion, while PdA1 achieved 48% selectivity with 87% conversation. However, indiscriminately reducing the particle size may lead to unfavorable outcomes, as confirmed by a series of Pd/Al2O3 catalysts with Pd particles ranging from 1 nm to 7 nm synthesized by wang et al. [87] The space-time yield (STY) of anthraquinone hydrogenation peaked at a particle size of 4 nm, as particles smaller than 4 nm may not supply enough atoms to form active centers. To enhance the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts, it has been proposed to decrease the low coordination sites in order to hinder the adsorption of CC. Qin et al. accurately coated the unsaturated coordination sites of Pt NPs with Fe oxide through the atomic layer deposition (ALD) method [88]. The CO diffuse-reflectance infrared fourier-transformation spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) results indicated that there was a lower percentage of low coordinated Pt sites on Pt30Fe30. Additionally, FeO x also prevents the Pt species from oxidation. The selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol over Pt30Fe30 was as high as 84% at 75% conversion. Furthermore, Claus and co-workers successfully synthesized well-faceted Au-based catalysts by introducing In elements for the selective hydrogenation of acrolein [89]. Such strategy facilitated the selective bonding of In to the exterior areas of the Au particles, which minimized the production of propionaldehyde by Au (111) and Au (100) and enhanced efficiency of the remaining active sites identified as CO activation edges in producing allyl alcohol. As a result, the selectivity of allyl alcohol was raised from 36% to 63%. 3.1.2 Shape and crystal faces Each crystal face of the metal particle displays a unique surface crystal field determining the transformation of the reactant into the desired product [107–109]. The shape effect of Pd-based and Pt-based monometallic catalysts was almost studied in the previous work and already discussed in the Sections 2.1 and 3.1.1. Recently, Sun et al. investigated the structural sensitivity of cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation over bimetallic Pt3Ni nanocrystal with a cubic shape enclosed by six (100) facets and an octahedral shape surrounded by eight (111) facets ( Fig. 3a).[11] Compared to the cubic shape, the close-packed (111) surface of the octahedral structure was preferred to activate the entire conjugated system and led to the complete hydrogenation of the molecule forming the SAL. DFT calculations showed that the corresponding binding energies of the most stable configurations of the intermediate (C6H5CHCH2CH2OH) on Pt3Ni (100) and Pt3Ni (111) surfaces were − 3.18 and − 2.18 eV, respectively, due to the relatively open surface structure of (100). Fig. 3b demonstrated the diverse adsorption mode of the intermediate on Pt3Ni (100) and Pt3Ni (111), indicating that the CH2OH group bonded on (100) had a shorter O-to-surface distance and that the CC bond had a relatively long distance to the crystal surface. Furthermore, the crystal facets of support have a great impact on the state of metal species dispersed upon and lead to distinct catalytic performance [109,110]. However, there is little research studying the influence of support crystal facets in the hydrogenation of UAL. Jiang’s group investigated the shape effect of La2O2CO3 with nanorods (NRs) and NPs morphologies in the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde to hydro-cinnamaldehyde [111]. As the viewpoint that the alkali ion can promote the adsorption of cinnamaldehyde through the CO, Pd supported the La2O2CO3-NRs catalysts possessing more medium-strength basic sites performed higher reaction activity. From this, the support crystal facets may affect the catalytic performance through its intrinsic chemical properties. Besides, according to Hu’s research, the hydrotalcite-derived Pt-based catalyst synthesized by hydrotalcite (HT, Mg6Al2(OH)16CO3.4 H2O) with a 2D layered double hydroxides (LDH) structure had better evaluation results than Pt/MgO-Al2O3, which indicated the structure superiority of catalysts with different supports [90]. The HT support facilitated the dispersion and reduction of Pt species and increased the Pt0 relative content to dissociate H2. The activation energy of furfural over Pt/HT is only 12.8 kJ/mol, while 17.2 kJ/mol over Pt/MgO-Al2O3. Thus, the crystal facets of support could affect the catalytic performance indirectly through its textural structure, such as specific surface area and pore size, to change the metal dispersion and alter the chemical properties of the active metal. Even so, a clear revelation of the support crystal facets functional rule in the hydrogenation of UAL to UOL is still required. 3.1.3 Electronic property modification Catalyst modified by promoters, such as the second metal, support, or other additives, has attracted increasing scientific interest [112–115]. These promoters are utilized to offset the imperfect intrinsic properties of group VIII metals and regulate the adsorption form of UAL through two strategies. One of the modification strategies involves creating electron-deficient metal centers acting as electrophilic sites to adsorb CO through the terminal O atom via electron transfer from the active metal to the promoter (P 1) ( Fig. 4a). The active metal Pt and Pd with the d-band vacancies of 0.55 and 0.6 can be adjusted to close to 1 by the addition of the promoter as an electron acceptor. Another strategy is increasing the electron density of the active metal by accepting electrons from promoters (P 2) (Fig. 4b). The electron-enriched active metal strengthens the four-electron repulsion to CC and encourages the H2 activation. Meanwhile, the electron-deficient promoter serves as an electrophilic site promoting CO adsorption. Catalysts designed through the P 2 strategy exhibit a synergistic effect between the UAL molecule and H2 activation sites, which is further discussed in Section 3.2. Xiong’s group successfully synthesized Pt-Co bimetallic catalysts incorporating Pt NPs supported by an amorphous Co-Asp polymer [91]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra revealed a substantial interaction between Pt and Co-Asp. Specifically, electrons transferred from Pt to Co species generated electron-deficient Pt δ+ species, which preferred to adsorb the CO bond. Furthermore, the Pt δ+ species accelerated the heterolytic dissociation of H2, and the subsequent formation of H+/H− pairs displayed enhanced activity towards the polar CO bond, resulting in a high TOF of 1132 h−1 and superior cinnamyl alcohol selectivity of 89.3%. Zhou and co-workers designed Ir-CoO x /Al2O3 hybrid catalysts with outside amorphous CoO x and inner Ir particles in close proximity for the selective hydrogenation of furfural [92]. XPS results indicated the electron transfer from Ir to CoO x , and the DFT study revealed that the Ir-CoO x interaction tailored the adsorption of furfural and assisted the desorption of furfuryl alcohol, eliciting an enhanced catalytic performance with ≥ 99% of selectivity and ≥ 98% conversion. Supports were also employed as promoters to modify the intrinsic electronic properties of the active metal [116–118]. Charge transfer from active metal to graphdiyne (GDY) was examined using X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) [93]. The electron transfer from Pt to the highly conjugated GDY leads to an upward shift of the antibonding state density, leading to an increase of the d-band vacancy of Pt close to 1. Usually, the emergence of these electron-deficient sites produced by SMSI is supposed to occur at metal-support interfaces. Volpe and co-workers explored the interaction of M (M=Pt, Au, and Cu) and CeO2 in the cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation [94]. The charge transfer from the metal atom to the support generated M δ+ species consisting of an M δ+-Ov-Ce3+ bonding environment with the interfacial reduced Ce ions [119]. This interfacial region was found to feature a bottom layer of M δ+ atoms linked to the Ov of CeO2 and a top layer of M0 atoms connected to the underlying M δ+ atoms. The M0-M δ+ interface exhibited strong chemical adsorption of UAL, and the activated substrates followed interaction with activated hydrogen which dissociated on the neighboring M0 atoms. More on catalyst interfacial effects will be comprehensively discussed in Section 3.3. 3.2 Synergistic Effects The electrophilic center of the catalyst demonstrates a preference for adsorbing CO by interacting with the terminal O atom, then the resulting intermediate interacts with the active H dissociated on the adjacent metal and forms UOL. The synergy between the active metal for H2 activation and the electrophilic active site for substrate adsorption enhances the activity and selectivity of the selective hydrogenation of UAL. This design strategy is particularly suitable for metals with poor adsorption selectivity for CO but strong dihydrogen/H2 dissociation capacities, such as Pd, Pt, or others [97]. The addition of promoters can contribute to modulating the adsorption mode of UAL and fully utilizing the original metal to produce active H atoms. Such promoters may take the form of the second metal or the support. Catalysts designed with different types of electrophilic sites based on the synergetic effect are summarized in this section, and their catalytic performances are shown in Table 2. 3.2.1 Synergistic Effects in Bimetallic Catalyst Bimetallic catalysts discussed in this part are developed with the intention of modifying the intrinsic electronic properties of the group VIII metals as previously mentioned in 3.1. Except for the P 1, the P 2 strategy focuses on catalysts that involve electron transfer from the promoter to the active metal (Fig. 4b). The high selectivity of UOL over these catalysts can be attributed to two enhanced mechanisms: the electron-rich active metal reduces the probability of CC hydrogenation due to four-electron repulsion and promotes the H2 dissociation simultaneously (m 1), and the electron-contributing promoter acts as an electrophilic site for CO bond activation (m 2). These bimetallic catalysts may exhibit both m 1 and m 2 mechanisms. So far, plenty of bimetallic catalysts have been developed for the hydrogenation of UAL to UOL, with alloys, intermetallic compounds, and other forms of bimetallic NPs. Recently, Hosono’s group developed RuFe alloy nanoparticles supported on C12A7:e− with the charge transfer from Fe to Ru evidenced by CO-DRIFT spectra [120]. The electron-deficient Fe atoms first activated CO via the end-on O atom, then the activated substrates interacted with the hydrogen species produced by two possible routes: H2 dissociated at the Ru surface and formed nonpolar H atoms via the homolytic pathway (route 1); H2 was heterolytically dissociated at the metal-support interface resulting H+/H− species (route 2). Ascribing to the synergistic effect between Fe and the Ru or Ru-C12A7: e− interface, the bimetallic catalyst was able to give 96.2% conversion and 96.7% selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol. A novel Pd-Ru/C bimetallic catalyst was also prepared for the hydrogenation of benzaldehyde by Likholobov et al. [122] Enhanced catalytic performance of 100% conversation and 80–90% selectivity obtained by facilitating the electrophilic activation of CO through increasing the fraction of electrophilic Pd sites. Additionally, the activation of H2 was accelerated owing to the H-H bond being less hindered during the number of accessible electrons at the external d-band was increased. Besides, Hu et al. synthesized PtNi alloys supported on SBA-15 for the hydrogenation of furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [121]. The excellent catalytic performance of the PtNi/SBA-15 ascribed to the charge transfer from Ni to Pt, and the as-formed Pt δ− species significantly facilitated the selective hydrogenation of CO. Intermetallic compounds possessing specific crystal structures and well-defined atomic arrangements demonstrate large metal-metal interface areas, which contribute to the intensification of electronic interaction in the catalysts [139–142]. Zhao et al. designed a Fe x Co@NC catalyst for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde with a transition-metal alloying method ( Fig. 5a) [123]. The original monometallic Co@NC catalyst performed high activity but poor selectivity attributed to the indiscriminate hydrogenation of the CC and CO bond at Co-N x sites, while the high selectivity over Fe x Co@NC of 91.7% with 95.1% conversation was obtained. XPS spectra demonstrated the charge transfer from Fe to Co, increasing the electron density of Co and suppressing the activation of the nucleophilic CC, and the electron lost Fe atoms facilitated the activation of CO simultaneously (Fig. 5b). DFT calculation revealed the adsorption energy of the vertical and parallel mode of cinnamaldehyde molecule adsorbed on the Co (111) and Fe-Co (110) were − 0.54, − 7.82, − 1.42, and − 7.18 eV, respectively, which indicated that the substrate preferred to absorb on the Fe-Co alloy with vertical configurations (Fig. 5c). Similarly, Lü et al. reported a NiIn0.2 intermetallic compound supported on MgO-Al2O3 for furfural hydrogenation ( Fig. 6a) [124]. The electron localization function (ELF) computation confirmed the electron transfer from In to Ni. DFT calculation showed the most stable adsorption structure of furfural on Ni2In (110) was vertical, while Ni (111) preferred parallel adsorption of furan ring and CO (Fig. 6(b, c)). However, the performance of intermetallic compounds could be impacted by the ratio of the metal species [123]. The study of Pt3Co@Co(OH)2 catalyzed cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation showed that the Pt3Co NPs exhibited similar performance to Pt NPs, with a 100% conversion and < 30% selectivity. While the subsequent introduction of Co(OH)2 significantly increased the selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol to 91.3% [125]. This might be explained by the insufficient ratio of Co on Pt3Co to produce enough electrons to Pt, and the consequent improvement in selectivity following the addition of Co(OH)2. Decorating metal NPs with metal oxides is another approach to leverage the synergistic effect. Tomishige et al. successfully designed an Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde in which Ir NPs were decorated by ReO x [126]. Ir metal heterolytic dissociated H2 to H+/H− pair leading to the high selectivity to crotyl alcohol, and ReO x promoted the CO group adsorption enhancing the catalytic activity and selectivity. Besides, Qin et al. reported a CoO x /TiO2/Pt catalyst with CoO x and Pt spatially separated by TiO2 nanotubes ( Fig. 7a) [127]. The CoO x /TiO2/Pt and CoO x Pt/TiO2 exhibited almost identical selectivity owing to the hydrogen spillover, but both presented higher selectivity than TiO2/Pt. In situ X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) and in situ Ti K-edge XANES spectra revealed the two steps of the enhancement mechanism: (a) the CoO x species disturbing the original equilibrium of hydrogen spillover by consuming the migrated hydrogen species and reducing itself to lower valent states, which contributes to the promotion of the active hydrogen species generation and spillover; (b) the high density of active hydrogen species leading to the reduction of TiO2 and creating more Ov sites (Fig. 7b). The Ov sites had a greater propensity to adsorb CO with an adsorption energy of − 2.38 eV, whereas the adsorption energy of CC was − 1.68 eV (Fig. 7c). As a result, the CoO x /TiO2/Pt and CoO x Pt/TiO2 catalysts possessing enhanced hydrogen spillover and adsorption sites performed a profound selectivity of 80% with > 90% conversation (Fig. 7d). 3.2.2 Metal-support synergetic effect The synergistic effect between metal and support is similar to that in the bimetallic catalysts. The active metal site for the H2 dissociation is still needed, and the positively charged sites on the support act as the electrophilic sites to activate CO instead of the adsorption site generated on the second metal through electron transfer [143,144]. Electrophilic sites on the surface of the support can be categorized into acid sites, Ov, the metal nodes of MOFs, and new adsorption sites formed on supports via electron transfer. In this section, catalyst designations based on such synergistic effects are discussed according to different types of electrophilic sites. The acid sites and Ov on metal oxide supports are proven can accelerate the adsorption of the CO bond in the early years [145–148]. Previously, Li et al. prepared a ZnO-promoted Cu-based nanocatalyst that exhibited over 75% selectivity toward allylic alcohol with complete conversion of citral, which attributed to the synergistic effect between Cu0/Cu+ species and the promotion of surface acid sites [128]. Besides, it is important to note that optimal performance is obtained only at the acid site with suitable reactant adsorption and product desorption energy. Strong Lewis acid sites on Al2O3 support often lead to low selectivity because of strong interactions with substrates [149]. Zaera et al. regulated the acid-base properties of Pt/Al2O3 with SiO2 thin films through an atomic layer deposition ALD method, resulting in an increase in selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol from less than 25% to at least 85% after 3 or 4 ALD cycles [129]. Catalysts with Ov synergized with active metal also provided the high catalytic performance of selective hydrogenation of UAL. Wu et al. developed a new Ni/TiO x catalyst to enhance the activity and selectivity of hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol [130]. The final catalytic performance of the catalysts depended on two interactions, wherein the TiO x donated electrons to Ni to inhibit the adsorption of CC, and the Ov of TiO x facilitated the adsorption of CO. The selectivity of furfuryl alcohol over the Ni/TiO x catalyst achieved 96.8% at 92.5% conversion under mild conditions. Additionally, CoAl-LDH-supported Pt catalysts with dual defects (Ov and cobalt vacancy) were designed by Li’s group [131]. The Pt-Ov-Co δ+ structure formed at the interface related to Ov altered the absorption mode of cinnamaldehyde and facilitated the activation of CO. The interface area regarded to cobalt vacancy, Pt-OCo-OH δ−, increased the spillover of active H species. Recently, Chen et al. successfully designed a novel catalyst with abundant Ov by dispersing Pt on partial deligandation of Ce-MOFs at 270 °C ( Fig. 8a) [132]. Compared with the Pt/CeO2-600 catalyst treated under 600 °C, Pt/CeO2-270 with residual organic ligands provided more defects and unsaturated metal sites which served as electrophilic sites to interact with the CO group and showed better activity and selectivity (Fig. 8(b, c, d, e)). MOFs comprised of networks of metal nodes or inorganic clusters bridged by organic ligands have proven to be effective supports for the hydrogenation of UAL [150–152]. The metal nodes of MOFs act as Lewis acid sites in synergy with the active metal, thereby enhancing the selectivity of UOL. Li’s group reported a Pt@HP-UiO-66 catalyst with a core-shell structure that encapsulated Pt NPs into the hierarchical pores of HP-UiO-66 equipped with plenty of exposed Zr4+ sites ( Fig. 9a) [133]. The Zr4+ acted as a Lewis acid site for the activation of CO, and the electron transfer from Pt to UiO-66 also generated plenty of electrophilic Pt δ+ sites (Fig. 9(b, c)). Ascribed to the abundance of Zr4+ and Pt δ+ species, this innovative catalyst demonstrated a high selectivity of 76% and 85% conversion in the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde (Fig. 9(d, e)). Guan et al. regarded that the interaction between metal NPs and MOFs should be of moderate strength [24]. The Ru/UiO-66 catalyst exhibited 94.9% conversion of furfuryl alcohol with nearly 100% selectivity, which was attributed to the easily reducible metallic Ru species formed on the surface of RuO x under reaction conditions. The coordination of metal nodes has been identified as a crucial factor affecting catalytic performance in the transfer hydrogenation of UAL. Among the various Zr-MOFs, MOF-808 with the lowest coordination number of 6 showed the highest catalytic activity [134]. Hara et al. found DUT-52 with stronger lewis acidity of Zr atoms compared to UiO-66 performed higher activity and selectivity [135]. Tong et al. synthesized a novel 2D Ni-based MOF (Ni-MFC) catalyst for the hydrogenation of furfural and concluded that Ni2+ in Ni-MFC was responsible for the higher yield of furfuryl alcohol while Ni0 resulted in the production of tetrahydro furfuryl alcohol [136]. However, the impact of metal node coordination on catalytic performance in heterogeneous selective hydrogenation with dihydrogen/H2 as the hydrogen source has yet to be extensively studied. Several positively charged sites formed by charge transfer between metal and support can also effectively increase the absorption of UAL through the CO group. For instance, Feng et al. synthesized a Pt/CoAl-LDHs catalyst with strengthened metal-support interactions owing to the Co2+-O2−-Al3+ structure of CoAl-LDHs [137]. The SMSI resulted in the formation of electron-rich Pt δ− sites and exposed abundant unsaturated coordination sites on the support, thereby enhancing the activation of H2 and the adsorption of cinnamaldehyde, respectively. Similarly, Gao et al. prepared a highly selective Ir/H-MoO x catalyst featuring SMSI between Ir and H-MoO x [138]. The negatively charged Ir δ− species that resulted from accepting the electrons supplied by H-MoO x effectively enhanced the repulsive force with CC, and the activation of CO was promoted by the H-MoO x support at the same time. 3.3 Interfacial effects Atoms situated at the metal-support interface have particularly electronic properties that are different from those located at the active center or the support. Studies established that such interfacial regions play an important role in the catalytic process [153–155]. Several reported catalysts having interfacial effects are discussed in this section and the evaluation results are summarized in Table 3. The application of reducible support presents a promising option for the selective hydrogenation of UAL, not only due to the Ov on the surface of the support which can synergize with the active metal species but also generate new active sites at the metal-support interface driven by SMSI [160–162]. Fig. 10(a, b) illustrates the charge distribution of Ir/Mo2C and Ir/SiO2 catalysts, with the former demonstrating stronger SMSI and generating more Ir δ− species at the interface, resulting in a notably higher crotyl alcohol selectivity of 80% than Pt/SiO2 (<30%) [156]. As well as Pt-based and Au-based Mo2C-supported catalysts with detectable Pt δ− and Au δ− presents a remarkably higher selectivity of 66% and 53%, respectively (Fig. 10(c, d, e)). The Pt3Sn/CNT catalyst synthesized by Liang et al. also performed a similar catalytic mechanism, where the incorporated Sn atoms effectively regulate the electron density of Pt to an electron-rich state, and SnO x formed at the interfaces acted as electrophilic sites facilitated the activation of CO [157]. In addition, a novel Pt/TiH2 catalyst was devised by Zhao and co-workers with hydrogen storage and release capability for cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation [158]. H atoms were first dissociated over Pt NPs via the homolytic pathway and moved onto the TiH2 surface. The H atoms then diffused into the internal surface of the support and transformed into H+/H− pairs through the interaction with titanium species and hydride vacancies therein. During the hydrogenation process, the cinnamaldehyde molecule initially adsorbed onto the Ov of the support via the CO bond and subsequently underwent hydrogenation through the H+/H− species stored in the thin TiO x H y layer. Ascribed to the unique Pt crystallite-support boundary layer, the selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol reached 97% with 98% conversion. Furthermore, Li et al. studied the interfacial effect of the PtFe x /Al2O3 @SBA-15 catalyst and found that there are two kinds of positively charged active sites that promote catalytic performance [159]. The first type is brønsted acid sites generated at the Al2O3 @SBA-15 interface owing to the interaction between alumina and silica. The second is the Pt δ+ species that arise from electron transfer from Pt to the support or FeO x , characterized by XPS, H2-TPR, and CO-DRIFTS. Both such positively charged active sites and FeO x acted as the electrophilic center which efficiently promoted the adsorption of terminal CO, and 76.9% selectivity and 1.54 s−1 TOF were achieved. Besides, Luo et al. synthesized a series of MoO x -promoted Ir/BN catalysts. On the bare 3Ir/BN catalyst, the high coverage of crotonaldehyde hindered the adsorption and dissociation of H2 on the Ir NPs surface ( Fig. 11a).[26] The Ir-MoO x interface constructed by adding the MoO x component facilitated the adsorption and activation of crotonaldehyde with a lower activation energy and preserved more Ir active surface for H2 dissociation, as illustrated in Fig. 11b. While high content of MoO x leading to less exposed Ir atoms made the difficulty of H2 dissociation (Fig. 11c). The selectivity of the desired product crotyl alcohol was increased from 76.6% to 88%, and TOF rose from 47.1 h−1 to 190.2 h−1. 3.4 Geometric effects The above-mentioned catalyst structure-performance relationships primarily concern the correlation between electron transfer/distribution and the adsorption/activation of the UAL molecule. Another effective strategy to enhance the selectivity is to impede the adsorption of the CC group by manipulating the geometry of the carrier or metal active center. Within the specific UAL molecules, CC bonds are positioned in the middle region of the molecular chain, and the substituent and CO occupied both ends, except acrolein. The incorporation of supports possessing unique structures or pores can hinder the adsorption of CC by the surrounding surface environment of the catalyst, and allows for only the end CO group to adsorb on the surface of the active center, thereby creating the steric effect. Additionally, the steric effect can also be triggered by selective poisoning of the metal NPs with organic modifiers, which is similar to the crystal face regulation elucidated in Section 3.1 but without electronic function. Besides, the steric environment generated by the larger substituent in the UAL molecules has already been detailed in Section 2. In this part, the discussion focuses on the steric effects engendered by supports and selective poisoning of the metal particle, and the catalytic performances are summarized in Table 4. 3.4.1 Steric effects Catalysts with metal NPs confined in the porous material have demonstrated increased selectivity towards UOL attributed to the steric effect. The architecture of the support plays a vital role in the adsorption and diffusion of reactant molecules, as well as the stability of the reaction intermediates [174–176]. The size of the reactant molecules and the pore diameter impact the likelihood of the functional groups being activated by the active metal. When the pore diameter is smaller than the free diameter of the reactant molecule containing two functional groups, only the terminal groups, such as the CO in UAL, can undergo selective hydrogenation [32,177]. Meanwhile, the presence of spatially isolated pores inhibits the migration and aggregation of metal species, leading to greater stability than the catalysts with metal NPs dispersed on the support surface. In addition, altering the intrinsic electronic properties of the active metal in the confined space through SMSI allows for the regulation of the activation energy barrier in a particular reaction path [178–181]. For instance, Ni’s group reported that Ru NPs dispersed on the graphite-support surface only exhibited 51% selectivity, while the Ru NPs coated by the mesoporous SiO2 layer led to an increased selectivity to 61% ( Fig. 12a) [163]. Additionally, Nishiyama et al. developed an Sn-modified SiO2-coated Pt catalyst, in which the Sn component used to activate the crotonaldehyde molecule and the Pt NPs employed for H2 activation were separated (Fig. 12b) [164]. The crotonaldehyde molecules were unable to reach the core Pt NPs through the pores of the SiO2 layer, and only can be adsorbed by SnO2 through the CO bond. With 4.1% of yield, the selectivity of crotyl alcohol reached 100%. Zeolite also serves as an optimal framework for confining metal particles [182–184]. Catalyst with well-defined Cu NPs encapsulated within titanium silicalite-1 (Cu@TS-1) was designed by an in situ fixed method achieving 74.7% selectivity and 45.9% conversion, while the Cu/TS-1 with Cu NPs dispersed on the TS-1 surface showed only 62.3% selectivity and 20.3% conversion [165]. Characterization results indicated that the TS-1 zeolite not only provided the spatial restriction for the UAL molecule but also induced an electronic interaction between encapsulated Cu NPs and Ti species, which enhanced the catalytic performance and stability of the catalyst. Moreover, the following Na ion exchange operation regulated the acid/basic property of the zeolite, suppressing side reactions and modulating the encapsulated Cu species into an electronic-rich state. The evaluation results showed the selectivity and conversion of furfural hydrogenation over Na-Cu/TS-1 increased to 98.1% and 93.0% respectively. Further, Liu et al. reported a series of materials that Pt NPs loaded on hollow CeO2 with different spatial locations and microenvironments [166]. As shown in Fig. 12c, the active metal spatial position had a significant impact on the catalytic selectivity, with Pt NPs confined at the inner surface of hollow CeO2 (Pt@CeO2) yielding near 70% selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol, while only 27.6% was obtained with Pt positioned at the outer surface. MOFs featuring uniform channels and high specific surface area are ideal hosts for the encapsulation of active metal species [185–191]. The molecular-size-commensurate pore oriented the linear approach of the UAL since the interspace between the metal active site and the channel was insufficient for the free rotation of the molecule. Huang et al. first developed a UiO-66-confined Pt nanocluster catalyst for cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation [167]. The steric effect of the pores allowed only the terminal CO bond of the cinnamaldehyde molecule to access the surface of Pt, and the middle CC bond was hardly activated ( Fig. 13a). The innovative Pt@UiO-66-NH2 catalyst demonstrated 87.9% selectivity and 85.9% conversion without any deactivation after ten times cycle tests. Numerous studies have since explored the use of MOFs to encapsulate metal NPs for the selective hydrogenation of UAL [192–195]. Huo et al. confined Pt NPs by three kinds of MOFs with different channel environments, including ZIF-8, ZIF-67, and UiO-66 (Fig. 13b) [168]. The citronellal hydrogenated to citronellol over Pt@ZIF-8 (100%) and Pt@ZIF-67 (100%) showed higher selectivity compared to Pt@UiO-66 (6.69%), which attributed to the smaller pores of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 (Fig. 13c). Additionally, Pt@ZIF-8 and Pt@ZIF-67 displayed markedly different activity due to the superior coupling of the d-band between Pt and Co in ZIF-67 leading to an intense electron transfer between Pt NPs and MOFs, in contrast to the Pt and Zn combination in ZIF-8. Zhu et al. utilized MIL-101 as the support and functionalized with the -NH2 group, which boosted the selectivity to 78.9% accompanied by 72.3% conversion in the cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation, and achieved 87.0% selectivity and 89.7% conversion in the furfural hydrogenation [169]. Such efficient catalytic performance was owed to the electronic effect of the N heteroatom of the -NH2 group on Pt NPs and the steric effect induced by the mesoporous structure of MIL-101. Particularly, Zhang and co-workers successfully developed core-shell structured Pt/CeO2 @MOF hybrids through a sodium poly-styrene-sulfonate (PSS)-induced microwave-assisted method [170]. The inclusion of CeO2 optimized the d-band center and surface electron density of Pt species by the strong interaction between Pt and CeO2. Moreover, the steric effect of UiO-66-NH2 enhanced the selective hydrogenation of the CO group. The Pt-CeO2 @UiO-66-NH2 catalyst exhibited a notable selectivity of > 99% with 99.3% furfural conversion and retained the effectiveness through five cycles without any changes. 3.4.2 Selective poisoning by organic modifiers Selective poisoning of the metal particle with organic modifiers such as thiol, amine, or secondary phosphine oxides is an effective strategy for modifying the surface properties of catalysts. First, the adsorption configuration of UAL can be modulated by introducing organic ligands with spatial resistance properties to the active metal ( Fig. 14(a, b)) [171,172]. The long alkyl chain of the modifier interacts with the substrate through van der waals forces, promoting the “end-on” adsorption mode of the reactant and hindering the hydrogenation of CC at the same time. Furthermore, thiols can modify the exposed active sites of the metal particles by forming densely packed monolayers on the terrace, with continuous metal sites covered and corner/edge sites maintained. In furfural hydrogenation, the de-carbonylation mainly occurred on terrace sites, whereas hydrodeoxygenation took place on steps and edges. The addition of 1-octadecanethiol blocked some of the terrace sites, which prevented the de-carbonylation of furfural and assisted furfuryl alcohol production (Fig. 14c) [173]. However, although the introduction of long-chain organic molecules into catalysts can optimize the selectivity of UAL hydrogenation, the catalytic activity usually decreased due to the coverage of metal active sites. Besides, such organic modifiers may fall off the catalyst surface and contaminate the reaction system, thereby compromising product quality. Consequently, research pertaining to this strategy has developed sluggishly in recent years. In summary, based on the theory of heterogeneous catalysis, recent representative developments in the catalyst designation for the selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL are systematically reviewed from the perspective of electronic effects, synergistic effects, interfacial effects, and geometric effects. Regulating active metal centers with specific particle sizes and crystal faces, adding a second metal, selecting and using appropriate support, and altering SMSI between metal and support are effective strategies for developing high-performance catalysts. Because the nanoparticle morphology of the active metal generally does not have difficulties with hydrogen dissociation, CO adsorption is the primary consideration in the nanocatalyst designation. Therefore, enhancing the CO adsorption and activation is the basic principle for the rational design of highly selective and active nanocatalyst. 4 Selective hydrogenation by single-atom-site catalysts Although significant progress in nanocatalyst designation for the selective hydrogenation of UAL has been achieved, there are still numerous challenges that remain to be resolved. Limited dispersion of active metals and insufficient metal utilization of nanocatalyst result in metal resource waste and increase operating costs for industries, particularly when precious metals are employed [196–199]. Besides, various studies have attempted to establish a relationship between catalyst structure and reaction performance to develop highly efficient catalysts. However, identifying the true active center is difficult due to the atoms exposed to the metal surface having different coordination environments [95,200,201]. The complexity of the surface environments of nanocatalyst makes it challenging to reveal the reaction mechanism and design novel catalysts. SASCs featuring uniform isolated active sites and maximized atom utilization have made great progress in recent years [202–204]. The improvements in single-atom synthesis strategies and characterization techniques have opened up opportunities for the utilization of SASCs in a wide range of reactions, such as electrochemistry, photocatalysis, and organic reactions [205–208]. In many cases, the catalytic performance of SASCs is comparable to, or even superior to, that of nanocatalysts [209–211]. So far, SASCs had developed various branches, such as dual-atom-site catalysts (DASCs), nano-single-atom-site catalysts (NSASCs), single-atom alloy catalysis (SAAs) to cater to reactions with varying characteristics [212,213]. The use of SASCs has facilitated an in-depth understanding of the relationship between active site and catalytic performance, providing other feasible synthetic strategies for catalyst preparation, and further developing a new measure to synthesize cheap and practical catalysts for research and industrial applications [214,215]. While, up to now, there has been relatively less exploration of the application of SASCs in the selective hydrogenation of UAL compared to nanocatalysts [177]. Designing SASCs or related catalysts with high reaction performance for selective hydrogenation of UAL could be an essential direction for future research. In this section, the developments in the field of selective hydrogenation of UAL over SASCs and related catalysts are comprehensively summarized and discussed from aspects of SASCs, DASCs, NSASCs, and SAAs, and the conversion and selectivity are listed in Table 5. Although the current research of SASCs designing for selective hydrogenation of UAL is still in its nascent stages and few instances are available for analysis, the pioneering advancements highlighted herein are aim to serve as valuable references for future research endeavors in the field of SASCs and related catalysts. 4.1 Single-Atom-Site Catalysts One of the serious challenges faced by SASCs is to prevent metal single atoms from undergoing migration and aggregation during preparation and reaction due to their high surface free energy. Therefore, a robust chemical bond is typically formed between the support and metal atom, thereby resulting in a low coordination environment of the single atom site [229–231]. As a result, SASCs with a homogeneous electronic and geometric structure provide exceptional electrophilic/nucleophilic centers that lead the target functional group to be recognized [232]. Taking advantage of the unique properties of SASCs to construct electron-deficient centers that act as electrophilic sites on the surface of catalysts can significantly enhance the activation of CO. Consequently, SASCs have the potential to provide superior selectivity compared to nanocatalyst in the selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL.[233,234]. 4.1.1 Carbon-based catalysts Carbon-based materials with outstanding electrical properties and diversified structures are crucial in stabilizing single atomic metal species. Particularly, the incorporation of O, N, P, and S in carbon frameworks facilitates the redistribution of charges and creates additional anchoring sites for single metal atoms [218–220]. An advanced Pd1/C3N4 catalyst synthesized through the facile spatial confinement-reduction method employed in selective hydrogenation of furfural by Li et al. [216] As shown in Fig. 15a, the metal atoms were intercalated into the matrix of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with the homogeneously dispersed nitrogen-rich “six-fold cavities”. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) images demonstrated the brighter Z-contrast of Pd single-atoms (Fig. 15b). In the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra, the existence of the Pd-N bond without the Pd-Pd coordination acting as the Pd NPs was indicated by the only peak of Pd1/C3N4 at 1.51 Å, and the FT-EXAFs illustrated that each Pd atom coordinates with approximately three nitrogen atoms on the support (Fig. 15(c, d)). The Pd-N bond resulted in the charge transfer from Pd to g-C3N4, producing a positively charged Pd single atom site that was characterized by XPS and XANES (Fig. 15(e, f)). With a homogeneous electronic and geometry structure and positively charged Pd atoms that can act as electrophilic sites, the Pd1/C3N4 catalyst exhibited 64% conversion and 99% selectivity with no appreciable degradation after 5 cycles. While Pd NPs/C3N4 only achieved 39% conversion and 99% selectivity (Fig. 15g). 4.1.2 Defect-rich materials-supported catalysts Reducible metal oxides with ample defects can stabilize metal atoms by establishing strong interactions between the metal single atom and the coordination site [164–166]. Otherwise, the strong metal-support interactions regulate the geometric and electronic features of the metal species, which affects the hydrogenation performance of the catalysts. Li et al. dispersed Ir atoms on the surfaces of the defective metastable phase of titanium dioxide (def-TiO2) and mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4), respectively [217]. XANES and XPS showed that the Ir species supported on both def-TiO2 and mpg-C3N4 were oxidized, and EXAFS further indicated that the average coordination number of Ir-O and Ir-Ti bonds in Ir1/def-TiO2 and Ir-N/O in Ir1/mpg-C3N4 is 3.2, 2.8, 3.8, respectively, which demonstrated the stronger interaction between Ir and def-TiO2. The first-principle calculation revealed that the d-band electrons of positively charged Ir atoms were modulated, resulting in larger adsorption energies. Meanwhile, the Ti atom adjacent to Ir on Ir1/def-TiO2 can form chemical bonds with furfural, which also facilitated selective hydrogenation, while other atoms except for Ir on Ir1/mpg-C3N4 do not participate in the reaction. As a result, Ir1/def-TiO2 exhibited 99% conversion and 99% selectivity. Chen’s group reported an Ir1 @CeO2 catalyst with atomically dispersed Ir species anchored on three-dimensional CeO2 spheres [218]. XPS, Raman, and XANES results indicated the charge transfer from Ir to CeO2 along with the formation of new Ir δ+-O2–-Ce3+ interface structures. The electrophilic atomic Ir δ+ sites favored the heterolytic dissociation of H2, and the produced H+/H− pair inclined to interact with the polar CO bond. Besides, the positively charged Ir δ+ promoted the CO activation via η1(O)/η1 adsorption mode (mentioned in Section 2). Therefore, the Ir1 @CeO2 catalyst exhibited excellent cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation activity with a conversion of 99% and remarkably high TOF of 770 h−1 and circa 100% selectivity. While the IrN+S@CeO2 catalyst containing both metal nanoparticles and single atoms and Ir NPs@CeO2 demonstrated poor selectivity despite obtaining more than 90% conversion. Moreover, the Ir1 @CeO2 catalyst also delivered excellent hydrogenation performance in other important UAL hydrogenation reactions (Table 5). MoS2 is also a feasible support for the designation of SASCs owing to the abundant defects [235–240]. Liu and co-workers successfully synthesized Rh1/MoS2 by depositing the Rh atom on the Mo edge vacancy site of the MoS2 sheet [219]. Similarly, the Rh1 atoms were positively charged due to the electron transfer from the Rh1 atom to the surrounding S atoms, which facilitated the adsorption of the CO bond ( Fig. 16a). Besides, characterization and DFT calculation results indicated that the Rh1/MoS2 catalyst exhibited a unique HO-Mo-Rh1-Mo-OH pocketlike configuration, which was constructed with the procedure of the hydrogen molecules first dissociated on the Rh1 atom, spilling over along the edge of the 2D MoS2 sheets, and bonding with the O atom (Fig. 16b, steps ii, iii, and iv). This unique geometric structure confined the parallel adsorption mode of the crotonaldehyde owing to steric effect (Fig. 16b, steps v), and the activation barrier of the hydroxylation process only 0.04 eV assisted by the OH group (Fig. 16b, steps v, vi). Thus, 100% selectivity with 64.7 h−1 TOF was achieved in the hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde to crotyl alcohol. Similarly, Yang et al. synthesized Pt1/MoS2 catalysts with comparable structures, which exhibited excellent performance with 40.5 h−1 TOF and 100% selectivity of crotyl alcohol at 75 °C and 6 bar H2 [220]. 4.1.3 Zeolites-supported catalysts Zeolites containing hydroxyl groups have proven to be effective host materials by encapsulating metal precursors within their cavities. Li et al. reported a Pt@Y catalyst with Pt single atoms engaged in the Y zeolite ( Fig. 17a) [221]. The Pt@Y catalyst had an individual structure where the isolated Pt δ+ atom was stabilized by the surrounding O atoms in the six-membered rings shared by sodalite cages and super-cages. The Pt δ+···O2− units formed in the structure facilitated the heterolytic dissociation of H2 to H+/H δ−, as confirmed by in situ FTIR spectroscopy. Hydroxyls exhibited different stretching vibrations with IR bands at 3714, 3668, 3565, 3466, and 3245 cm−1, which manifested the combination of protons with the O atom in the zeolite framework. Additionally, the existence of Pt-H2 species was indicated by IR bands at 2355/2358 and 2344 cm−1 (Fig. 17b). Pt/Y showed a stronger band intensity in FTIR spectra, substantiating the easier formation of Pt-H2 on metallic Pt rather than cationic Pt in Pt@Y. The H+/H δ− pair generated at Pt@Y improved the selective hydrogenation of the polarity CO bond compared to H atoms homolytic dissociated on Pt/Y (Fig. 17(c, d)). 4.2 Dual-atom-site catalysts Dual-atom-site catalysts (DASCs) typically contain two metal atoms located in one single active center, or two distinct metal single-atom active sites showing synergetic effects in catalysis. Current research has classified DASCs into three categories: the two metal atoms at the active site are identical (named homonuclear DASCs), and the two distinct metal atoms are situated on a single active site or are isolated single-atom active sites (both named heteronuclear DASCs) [241–245]. DASCs have superior catalytic performance compared to SASCs, particularly when catalyst properties can be adjusted through the regulation of the second metal atom sites[246–251]. Li’s group successfully synthesized a Pt2/mpg-C3N4 DASC which mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4) supported Pt dual-atom through a wet-chemical method ( Fig. 18a) [222]. The existence of the dual-atom Pt2 structure was confirmed by HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 18b) and EXAFS spectra showed the Pt-N/O interaction at 1.62 Å and Pt-Pt bonds at 2.44 Å. XANES spectra revealed that the two Pt atoms were positively charged, similar to Pt1/mpg-C3N4 (Fig. 18(c, d)). According to the mechanism and computational energy profile of benzaldehyde hydrogenation over Pt2/mpg-C3N4, the novel dual-atom-site catalyst overcomes some of the shortcomings of the single atom site Pt1/mpg-C3N4 catalyst of the high energy barrier of the H2 dissociation and the disadvantage of difficult desorption of products in Pt NPs catalysts (Fig. 18e, S1, S5→S6). Pt2/mpg-C3N4 showed exceptional catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of benzaldehyde to benzyl alcohol, with over 99% conversion and selectivity achieved under the conditions of 120 °C and 8 MPa H2 (Fig. 18f). 4.3 Nano-Single-Atom-Site Catalysts Downsizing nanoparticles to single atoms is an effective way to achieve 100% atomic utilization, while SASCs do not always exhibit efficient catalytic performance in various reactions, especially when multiple active centers are required for substrate adsorption.[251–253] As aforementioned in Sections 2.2, 4.1, and 4.2, the heterolytic pathway for H2 dissociation on SASCs with positively charged metal species surrounded by negatively charged ligands has a much higher energy barrier than the homolytic pathway on a bulk metal surface.[254–256] Thus, the hydrogenation progress of UAL is hampered by the limited activity of SASCs in H2 activation. Therefore, designing SASCs or related catalysts without inhibition of H2 dissociation is the most promising strategy for the selective hydrogenation of UAL. Nano-Single-Atom-Site Catalysts (NSASCs) combine the merit of the 100% metal utilization of SASCs and the high-efficiency hydrogen dissociation ability of nanocatalysts [257–260]. The electrophilic M1 sites in NSASCs provide numerous adsorption sites for the CO group, and the metal NPs enhance the dissociation of H2. For instance, Li et al. designed Pd1+NPs/TiO2 catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of UAL under room temperature, and the process of CO adsorption and H2 dissociation on Pd1/TiO2 (110) and metallic Pd (111) surfaces was studied by DFT calculation, respectively ( Fig. 19(a, b)) [223]. The results showed that the UAL molecule preferred to adsorb on Pd1 sites (−0.92 eV) by the η1(O)/η1 mode rather than Pd (111) (−0.34 eV) (Fig. 19c). And H2 dissociation was inhibited at the Pd1 site and preferentially occurred on Pd NPs, due to the increased adsorption energy of H2 on Pd1/TiO2 (1.27 eV) compared with Pd (111) (0.78 eV) (Fig. 19d). Thus, Pd1 and Pd NPs severally dedicated to activating CO and H2. The synergistic mechanism in NSASCs overcomes the H2 dissociation difficulties with SASCs and Pd NPs resulting in significant improvement in the catalytic performance of Pd1+NPs/TiO2, as shown in Fig. 19e. 4.4 Single-atom alloys Single-atom alloys (SAAs) constituting of high activity metal species with low selectivity and less reactive but selectively host metals gained much attention in the last few years [261–265]. Noble metals such as Pt and Pd are preferred as guest active species due to their high H2 dissociation ability, and the host metals are typically selected based on their appropriate adsorption/desorption strength with reactant/product molecules such as Ag and Cu [212]. The synergistic effect between host and guest metal resulted in the outstanding performance of SAAs in the selective hydrogenation of UAL. The initial experimentation conducted by Meyer’s group developed a Pd/Ag SAAs catalyst with Pd single atoms dispersed on Ag nanoparticles for the selective hydrogenation of acrolein [224]. DFT calculation showed that the Pd/Ag (111) surface exhibited a reduction in H2 activation energy from 1.15 eV (Ag (111)) to 0.31 eV, in addition to weakened binding energy of − 0.33 eV from − 1.23 eV (Pd (111)), which demonstrated Pd atoms on Ag (111) surface facilitated the dissociation of H2 and the active H atoms subsequently spilled over to the Ag (111) surface due to the lower binding energy ( Fig. 20a). As the Pd species content increased, the activity was found to increase gradually while the selectivity of target allyl alcohol decreased. DFT calculation of acrolein adsorbed on the Pd/Ag (111) surface explained such phenomenon that the Pd single-atom active sites preferred to bond with acrolein through CC rather than CO (Fig. 20b). A similar mechanism was also reported by Trenary et al. in the Pd/Ag SAAs system for acrolein hydrogenation [225]. Besides, a series of Pd/Cu SAAs were designed for the hydrogenation of furfural by Kyriakou et al.[226] The selectivity of Pd/Cu SAAs has been optimized compared to monometallic Pd catalysts, which attributed to the Pd single active site avoiding the adsorption orientation through the five-membered ring that usually occurs on the Pd flat surface. Contrary to the hydrogenation of acrolein over Pd/Ag (111), the selectivity of Pd/Cu SAAs for furfuryl alcohol is almost equal to 98% even when the proportion of Pd species changed. That may be because the Pd single atom site priority adsorbed the acrolein molecule through the CC bond, while the furfural molecule prefers to be adsorbed on the Pd NPs surface through η2(C, O)-aldehyde bonding modes, and the furan ring cannot be activated at metal single-atom sites and is inactive in hydrogenation compared to CC.[266] Furthermore, the Pd/Cu SAAs with isolated Pd atoms enhanced hydrogen dissociation following H atoms spilled over to the Cu surface, performing an increase conversion to 40.1% from 23.1% of monometallic Cu catalyst. Zaera and co-workers prepared Pt/Cu SAAs with the structure that a thin Cu oxide layer covering the surface of Cu NPs supported on SBA-15 for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde ( Fig. 21a) [227]. The addition of a small amount of Pt to the Cu NPs substantially improved the activity and selectivity (Fig. 21b). DFT calculations identified that Pt single-atom sites facilitated the initial activation of H2, and the main hydrogenation steps took place on the Cu surface with the UAL molecule adsorbed through the terminal CO bond. In addition, they studied the influence of different molar ratios of Pt/Cu on the selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol through DFT calculation and microkinetic simulations [228]. As shown in Fig. 21c, Pt surface performed poor selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol owing to the formation rate constant of dihydro-cinnamaldehyde (k′ HCMA) being faster than that for CMO production (k′ CMO). As the Pt content increased, both the above rate constants showed a decrease along with the molar ratio of Pd/Cu in the range of 0.005–0.05 and then increased in the range of 0.05–0.1. The value of k′ CMO/k′ HCMA peaked at 0.005, corresponding to a CMO selectivity of 70%. In conclusion, the present investigation on the application of SASCs in selective hydrogenation of UAL has revealed that the positively charged metal atoms in SASCs are conducive to the adsorption of CO, and H2 heterolysis dissociated on the active sites has the potential to considerably enhance the selectivity. Nonetheless, the high dissociation energy of H2 at the single-atom site resulted in the poor activity of SASCs. Therefore, the activation of H2 might be the priority consideration in the SASCs/related catalysts designation. Conversely, DASCs reduce the dissociation energy barrier of H2 ,and generate more active H atoms. Notably, the development of NSASCs overcomes the high H2 dissociation energy barrier of SASCs, the UAL molecules are primarily activated at the single atom sites and further hydrogenated by H atoms homolytic dissociated at the nearby metal NPs. Additionally, SAAs combine the advantages of high activity and high selectivity of the two components in the alloy, but the active metal utilized to dissociate H2 remains in a single atom form that is difficult to activate H2. According to the above, DASCs and NSASCs could be deemed as the most potential catalysts due to their superior adsorption and activation ability of UAL and H2. 5 Conclusion and perspectives This review summarizes the recent representative publications about the selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL over NPs and SASCs/related catalysts and systematically investigates the structure-performance relationship of the catalysts. Firstly, the adsorption mode of the substrate at the metal active sites and the activation pathway of H2 are discussed. Herein, the on-top, diσco, and πco absorption modes or electron-deficient sites contribute to higher UOL selectivity, and the H+/H– pair dissociated by the heterolytic pathway is more selectively but kinetically unfavorable. Secondly, the functional mechanism of the nanocatalyst in selective hydrogenation of UAL is analyzed through the aspect of electronic effects (particle size, edges, crystal face, electron transfer), metal-metal and metal-support synergistic effects, interfacial effects, and geometric effects of steric effects and selective poisoning. Lastly, the applications of SASCs and related catalysts in the selective hydrogenation of UAL in terms of SASCs, DASCs, NSASCs, and SAAs, are summarized, and their unique catalytic mechanisms are revealed through various characterization methods and DFT calculations. Despite significant advancements in catalyst designation and synthesis achieved in recent years, certain obstacles and challenges as follows persist in the development of efficient catalysts for selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL: 1: A thorough comprehension of the structure-performance relationship of catalysts at the molecular level is essential to enhancing catalytic performance. For NPs, atoms positioned at crystal faces, defects, edges, or flat crystal surfaces have completely different electronic properties, resulting in distinct catalytic performance. Therefore, the specific function mechanism of NPs remains less discovered because of the complicated surface environment. SASCs possessing uniform active centers with controllable geometry and electronic properties are conducive to revealing the catalytic mechanism, with the assistance of advanced characterization methods and DFT calculation. Rationally regulating the texture, structure, and component of the catalyst at an atomic or molecular level, directional hydrogenating the unsaturated CO bond, restraining the hydronation of CC, and reducing the formation of by-products is pivotal to achieving "high activity and selectivity" in the selective hydrogenation process. 2: The high selectivity obtained is often accompanied by a loss of activity, especially when NPs are encapsulated by the support, due to the precise regulation of molecular adsorption modes causing the sacrifice of active site accessibility. According to the study of Huo et al., the TOF of the Pt@ZIF-67 catalyst with the Pt confined in ZIF-67 was only 42.28 h−1, while Pt NPs dispersed on the support surface is 119.14 h−1.[168] Even changing the electronic properties of the metal through a second metal or metal oxide support, the generation of the electron-deficient metal active center as the electrophilic site also suppress the activation of H2, or the electron-rich metal active center weaken the adsorption of the UAL. Therefore, designing bifunctional catalysts with complete separation of active sites of substrates and H2 is an effective strategy to achieve both high selectivity and activity. These materials have adjustable active sites that do not affect one another, and reactant molecules are activated at the adsorption site and then hydrogenated by the H atoms dissociated at the adjacent metal components. Catalysts with synergistic effects between active metal and the Ov/acid sites of support and NASCs may be the potential high-performance catalysts with detached active centers. 3: With the ever-increasing stringency of environmental-friendly requirements, it is imperative to minimize the production of by-products, while also emphasizing the judicious use of resources, especially precious metal resources are scarce and increasing in price year after year. Pt and Pd are the commonly used metal species in the selective hydrogenation of UAL, thus enhancing the exploration of promising catalysts with high atomic utilization, such as Pt/Pd-based SASCs/related-SASCs, is necessary. In addition, the development of high-performance noble metal with well-defined facets or non-precious metal catalysts that potentially replace precious metal catalysts has great value significance. Currently, Ni and Co are proven to achieve high performance for selective hydrogenation of UAL other than precious metals.[267,268] While their activities require improvement in light of their weak dihydrogen/H2 dissociation ability and UAL adsorption capacity. 4: SASCs have been extensively studied in recent years and showed impressive performance in various reactions. However, their application in selective hydrogenation of UAL lagged behind that of nanocatalysts. With their potential to conserve energy and enhance catalyst performance, SASCs/related catalysts hold great research value and application prospects. Therefore, the development of SASCs or related catalysts with excellent performance will be a popular research area in the future. Furthermore, more advanced in situ characterization techniques are needed to gain a better understanding of the unique mechanism of UAL hydrogenation over SASCs or related catalysts. In summary, comprehending the reaction mechanism and the impact of catalyst physicochemical properties on the hydrogenation performance, and establishing the structure-performance relationships of NPs/SASCs is the effective approach to designing high-performance catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes/ketones (UAL) to unsaturated alcohols (UOL) is a crucial reaction process in the fine chemical industry. Numerous efforts have been made to hydrogenate the target CO group to UOL due to the CC bond being more sensitive to reduction from both kinetics and thermodynamics. The key issue to designing catalysts with high performance is investigating and determining the structure-performance relationship in the selective hydrogenation of UAL. In this Review, the adsorption and activation mechanism of the reactants, and the influences of catalysts structures (electronic effects, synergistic effects, interfacial effects, and geometric effects) are comprehensively discussed. Additionally, the single-atom site catalysts and related catalysts including single-atom-site catalysts, dual-atom-site catalysts, nano-single-atom-site catalysts, and single-atom alloys, that applicated in UAL selective hydrogenation are systematically reviewed with a focus on the selective-enhancing mechanism. Finally, a brief perspective is provided to demonstrate the challenges as well as opportunities for rational designing advanced catalysts toward selective hydrogenation of UAL to UOL.
coredata.dc:title: Rational design of catalysts for heterogeneous selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes/ketones: From nanoparticles to single atoms
